title: Malcolm Turnbull says nobody at G20 defended North Korea missile test
content: Malcolm Turnbull said “nobody” at the G20 table was defending North Korea’s latest missile test, including China, despite the group’s failure to produce a unanimous statement condemning the rogue state. Speaking in Paris on Sunday, Turnbull said he had hoped to see the G20 deliver a statement on North Korea. He said it simply “was not able to be achieved”. “I just want to be very clear about this, nobody around that table was defending the North Koreans, in terms of their conduct,” Turnbull told reporters. “It is the Chinese of course, as I’ve said before, who have the greatest leverage and hence the greatest responsibility,” he said. “[They] are very forthright in their condemnation of North Korea’s conduct, and indeed in supporting the sanctions that have been imposed by the security council.” The failure to deliver a unanimous statement on North Korea was seen by some commentators as a sign of waning US influence. In analysis that has gone viral, ABC political editor Chris Uhlmann, described it as a consequence of Donald Trump’s poor leadership. But Turnbull maintained the United States, through Trump’s presence in Hamburg, continued to demonstrate global leadership. “The US is a global leader, plainly,” Turnbull said. “It is the largest economy, it is the number one superpower. It provides global leadership and the president’s presence at Hamburg was demonstration of that. “But again that doesn’t mean that everybody has to agree on every single point.” The most glaring area of difference at the meeting’s conclusion was on climate change. Nineteen of the 20 countries recommitted to the Paris climate change accord, leaving only the US in the cold. That prompted a communique from the G20, which read: “We take note of the decision of the United States of America to withdraw from the Paris agreement,” adding: “The leaders of the other G20 members state that the Paris agreement is irreversible” and “we reaffirm our strong commitment to the Paris agreement”. Turnbull said progress on climate change had been made at the G20, despite the US position. “Plainly there are some differences of opinion around the table, but you can have a good outcome … without having unanimity on every single point,” Turnbull said. Turnbull said Australia had sought and achieved agreements on terror and “challenges in the cyber sphere”.
summary:
Malcolm Turnbull said “nobody” at the G20 table was defending North Korea’s latest missile test, including China, despite the group’s failure to produce a unanimous statement condemning the rogue state.
Speaking in Paris on Sunday, Turnbull said he had hoped to see the G20 deliver a statement on North Korea.
It provides global leadership and the president’s presence at Hamburg was demonstration of that.
Nineteen of the 20 countries recommitted to the Paris climate change accord, leaving only the US in the cold.
Turnbull said progress on climate change had been made at the G20, despite the US position.
